Name: Tolfenpyrad
Description: Tolfenpyrad is an aromatic amide obtained by formal condensation of the carboxy group of 4-chloro-3-ethyl-1-methylpyrazole-5-carboxylic acid with the amino group of 1-[4-(4-methylphenoxy)phenyl]methylamine. It has a role as a mitochondrial NADH:ubiquinone reductase inhibitor, an agrochemical, an EC 1.3.5.1 [succinate dehydrogenase (quinone)] inhibitor and an antifungal agent. It is a pyrazole insecticide, an aromatic amide, an aromatic ether and an organochlorine compound.

plant_translocations.content: The analysis of residue levels in different matrices, such as citrus peel and pulp, revealed varying concentrations of four pesticides—novaluron, pyriproxyfen, thiacloprid, and tolfenpyrad. Citrus peel consistently exhibited higher residue levels compared to other matrices, ranging from 0.051–0.40 mg/kg for novaluron, 0.063–0.37 mg/kg for pyriproxyfen, 0.24–1.0 mg/kg for thiacloprid, and 0.36–3.6 mg/kg for tolfenpyrad. In contrast, citrus pulp had the lowest residue levels, and the pesticides could be categorized into two groups based on their values. Pyriproxyfen and thiacloprid residues in citrus pulp were consistently below the limits of quantification (LOQs) at three sampling intervals of 14, 21, and 28 days. However, both novaluron and tolfenpyrad were detected in citrus pulp, albeit at lower concentrations of 0.01–0.063 mg/kg and 0.01–0.039 mg/kg, respectively. These findings confirm that pyriproxyfen and thiacloprid are non-systemic pesticides, as they did not translocate significantly into the citrus pulp. Conversely, novaluron and tolfenpyrad were detected in the pulp, indicating their systemic nature. The residue levels of these pesticides in citrus samples at 14, 21, and 28 days after spraying ranged between 0.018–0.12 mg/kg for novaluron, 0.013–0.076 mg/kg for pyriproxyfen, 0.027–0.19 mg/kg for thiacloprid, and 0.075–0.64 mg/kg for tolfenpyrad.
plant_translocations.reference: Dong, M., Wen, G., Tang, H., Wang, T., Zhao, Z., Song, W., … Zhao, L. (2018). Dissipation and safety evaluation of novaluron, pyriproxyfen, thiacloprid and tolfenpyrad residues in the citrus-field ecosystem. Food Chemistry, 269, 136–141. doi:10.1016/j.foodchem.2018.07.005

method.Plant Grown Condition: Citrus trees grown in Shanghai under varying weather conditions ranging from 4 °C to 38 °C, with an accumulative rainfall of 1369.7 mm. Samples collected at different intervals after the final spray of pesticides.
method.Chemical preparation: Standards of novaluron, pyriproxyfen, thiacloprid, and tolfenpyrad obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. The suspension concentrate (SC) formulations of these pesticides for field trials were provided by different companies. HPLC-grade reagents (acetonitrile, n-hexane, and methanol) were purchased from ANPEL Laboratory Technologies, Inc. Pure water was prepared using Milli-Q purification. Florisil SPE column (500 mg, 3 mL) was purchased from ANPEL Laboratory Technologies, Inc.
method.Received pesticide of plant: Four SC formulations of novaluron, pyriproxyfen, thiacloprid, and tolfenpyrad were applied in field trials on citrus trees in Shanghai. The application times, doses, and intervals varied for each pesticide.
method.Other Information: Three replicates were performed for each treatment, with three citrus trees considered one experimental plot.
